awd_titl_txt: CSBR:   Natural History: Enhancing paleontology collections in coordination with a new Burke Museum facility
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to the University of Washington to support the Burke Museum paleontology collection.  The Burke's paleontology collection includes approximately 3 million objects, but a substantial number of these are not easily accessible to the public or even to researchers and scholars because they are currently housed offsite at a variety of locations.  A primary goal of this project will be to bring together all of these offsite collections into a new facility.  The new Burke Museum building will maximize accessibility to the collections, as well as to provide the best environment, with modern temperature and humidity controls (not available at some of the current offsite facilities).  In addition, the design of the new building features labs and collections facilities visible to the public as well as two classrooms, which will further enhance the accessibility of the paleontology collections to the general public and students at the University of Washington.

The Burke Museum consolidation of three collections form three offsite storage facilities will offer increased safety for the fossils and enhanced accessibility and potential for research and instructional use.  As currently housed, the paleontology collections are severely compressed and the space available for research-related growth is limited.  Recent 5-year growth rates for the three main collections (invertebrate paleontology 3%, paleobotany 46%, and vertebrate paleontology 20%) demonstrate remarkable productivity from the ongoing research of the PIs, their students, and other Burke-associated researchers.  Funds from this award will be used for storage equipment, primarily cabinets and open-shelving units, to assure sufficient space for continued productivity.  As a university-based natural history museum, the Burke places great importance on training future paleontologists in a museum environment.  Undergraduate and graduate students will be employed throughout the proposed collections improvement project, giving them greater insight into how collections are created, maintained, and used.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Burke Museum (UWBM) is the Washington State museum of natural history and culture and is the largest museum of its kind in the Pacific Northwest region, housing over 16 million objects. The UWBM is located on the University of Washington (UW) campus and Burke curators are faculty members of academic departments across campus that do research and teach and train both graduate and undergraduate students. The UWBM has a well-established paleontology program with its four curators and three full-time collections staff, as well as almost 30 other affiliated paleontology researchers, three postdoctoral researchers, up to 13 graduate students, and over 900 undergraduates taking paleontology classes each year. UWBM fossil collections contain over 3 million specimens, including fossils of invertebrates (e.g., snails), microscopic marine organisms (e.g., algae), plants, and vertebrates (e.g., dinosaurs and mammals).

In 2019, construction of a new, 113,000-square-foot museum (the "New Burke") was concluded. In this new building, paleontology occupies approximately 4,500 square feet of exhibit area and 8,000 square feet of space for collections, labs, and offices. The New Burke turns the museum "inside-out," breaking down traditional museum barriers and inviting visitors to be part of a working museum. For example, there are five areas where visitors are able to view work going on in paleontology labs and collections rooms, and a part-time collections interpreter was hired to facilitate engagement with the public.

The two major goals of this CSBR project were to: 1) add storage capacity for paleontology collections (vertebrate paleontology, invertebrate paleontology, micropaleontology, and paleobotany), which are expected to grow each year as more specimens are collected for research (by, e.g., graduate students, volunteers, staff, faculty) or are donated to the museum; and 2) bring fossil specimens that were housed in three offsite storage locations to the New Burke museum building so that they are more safe and accessible for study by researchers.

The CSBR funds accomplished our first goal by allowing us to purchase specimen cabinets for regular-sized and smaller fossils (including microfossils) and open-shelving units for larger specimens (e.g., dinosaurs). As a result, we have space to grow our collections and house our offsite collections in the New Burke. However, because the grant budget was significantly decreased, we were not able to move offsite collections to the New Burke. The new storage units and the reorganization of the collections that happened as a result contribute to improved research capabilities in our collections space. The improvements also support our broader mission of allowing the public to directly see and learn about collections work and research in the visible paleo spaces in the new museum.

The grant also facilitated training in museum organization and collections improvement, which is important for our paleontology students. Specifically, the work to receive and install the new cabinets and shelves was carried out by six UW students, one research associate, and one collections facilitator. One UW graduate student was also supported by UWBM funds to assist with collections management once the new storage units were installed.

We have disseminated information about the collections improvement work to the public through social media (e.g., the UWBM's Twitter and Instagram accounts). The new collections were also going to be featured in several scientific conferences hosted at the New Burke, such as the Midcontinent Paleobotanical Colloquium (2020, 2021); however, because of COVID, these conferences had to be held virtually. Nonetheless, the images from the New Burke paleontological collections space and exhibits that were prominently featured on the conference websites ensured that the scientific community were made aware of the substantial improvements to the UWBM's paleontological collections and research spaces.
